awd_titl_txt: GP-EXTRA: Stimulating Hispanic Participation in the Geosciences (SHIP-GEO)
awd_abstract_narration:
Geoscience is vital to understanding and solving crucial global threats such as shortages of water, energy and food, and mitigating natural hazards in the coming century. However, the geoscience workforce in the US is facing not only a serious shortage for the coming decade, but the field struggles to keep pace with the changing national demographics. Of all of the STEM fields, geoscience has the least ethnic diversity, with Hispanics accounting for only ~3%, suggesting a clear consequence of the historically low enrollment of Hispanic students in geoscience fields. The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV), with its rapidly growing Environmental and Earth Sciences (EES) program, is the nation's second-largest Hispanic-serving institution with ~29,000 students (~90% Hispanic). UTRGV's strategic location along the international border with Mexico, as well as its founding principles, make it an ideal hub to nurture geoscientists from South Texas and beyond.

The goals of "GP-EXTRA: Stimulating Hispanic Participation in the Geosciences (SHIP-GEO)" at UTRGV are to contribute to reducing the US geoscience workforce shortage predicted for the coming decade and to increase Hispanic participation. SHIP-GEO aims to double, within five years (two years beyond NSF support), the annual number of graduates from the Environmental and Earth Sciences program. These goals are being achieved by hosting activities geared toward student recruitment and retention while building a mentoring network of students and alumni. The alumni mentors are helping to direct the students in their career and future success. The project has four objectives: (1) grow the existing EES program at UTRGV with the specific aim to recruit and retain students in geoscience; (2) increase community awareness of Earth systems; (3) guide community college and high school students into geoscience careers; and (4) expose undergraduate students to research as a path to graduate school. These objectives are being achieved through: pairing undergraduate majors with alumni who are working in the field of interest of the student; encouraging the transfer of community college students into the EES program at UTRGV through field trips, guest speakers, and an annual alumni career day; and expanding undergraduate research opportunities by engaging students in ongoing projects. The project also is awarding fifty scholarships to five cohorts of students over three years. SHIP-GEO contributes to the NSF's goal of increasing diversity in the geoscience pipeline by attracting, supporting and preparing Hispanic students for careers in geosciences in South Texas, and is expected to become one of the best-known programs in the nation for producing quality Hispanic geoscientists.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of "GP-EXTRA: Stimulating Hispanic Participation in the Geosciences (SHIP-GEO)" at UTRGV were to contribute to reduce the US geoscience workforce shortage predicted for the coming decade and to increase Hispanic participation. These goals were tackled by hosting activities geared toward student recruitment and retention while building a mentoring network of students and alumni. The project has four objectives: (1) grow the existing Earth and Environmental Sciences (EES) program at UTRGV with the specific aim to recruit and retain students in geoscience; (2) increase community awareness of Earth Systems; (3) guide community college and high school students into geoscience careers; and (4) expose undergraduate students to research as a path to graduate school. Project objectives were achieved through pairing undergraduate majors with alumni who were working in the field of interest of the student; encouraging the transfer of community college students into the EES program at UTRGV through field trips, guest speakers, and an annual alumni career day; and expanding undergraduate research opportunities by engaging students in ongoing projects.

Intellectual Merit. In integration with project components to attract and encourage UTRGV students into Geosciences, SHIP-GEO was able to provide 60 students with scholarships. Out of those students, 90% are Hispanic while 10% are non-Hispanic. SHIP-GEO Scholars were mainly majored in Environmental Sciences, Civil Engineering, and Biology (~95%), while few from non-STEM fields such as communication.  Gender-wise 62% of SHIP-GEO Scholars are female and 38% are male students. SHIP-GEO Scholarships greatly impacted students at UTRGV.  50% of SHIP-GEO Scholars landed a job after graduation in private or public sectors. 18% of SHIP-GEO Scholars are currently in graduate programs for their master degrees at UTRGV (currently ranked as R2) or at reputed R1 universities such as UT-Austin or UT-El Paso. 5% of SHIP-GEO Scholars (now seniors) will be applying for graduate school. 2% of SHIP-GEO Scholar will be starting her PhD student at R1 right after her graduation in Fall 2022.  Status of other 25% of SHIP-GEO Scholars are unknown as of date this report. The remaining 2% of SHIP-GEO Scholar dropped out from program from unknow reason. Students (both UTRGV and South Texas College, STC) participated in local field trips with transportation provided, which included aspects of coastal environment, soil sciences, water resources, mineral mining, aquatic systems, and sedimentology. Family such as parents and siblings were invited and participated in regional field trips to Earth System environment in the Rio Grande Valley (RGV). Field trips had impacted ~500 people (open to all disciplines) including students from STC and student from local high schools.

Broader Impacts. SHIP-GEO had impact on the development of the principal geosciences, and on other disciplines.  SHIP-GEO also impacted the development of human resources.  Upon its implementation, SHIP-GEO had become a recognized name in UTRGV, particularly among students outside Environmental Science on campus and among the local community.  Record high Environmental Science students and SHIP-GEO Scholarship awardees applied and earned summer internships at state/federal agencies. SHIIP-GEO helped students with their professional talks, extracurricular trainings/certificates, and career opportunities. SHIP-GEO had played a key role in inspiring/motivating students from a wide range of majors to explore potential career paths in geosciences, such as graduate school or employment opportunities.  Students expressed appreciations and how great the impacts from the training, opportunities, advice/guidance that SHIP-GEO team and supporting faculty provided. SHIP-GEO helped students build confidence. Multiple students participated in summer internships nationwide. SHIP-GEO provided multiple opportunities of training and professional development for both students and faculty and had broadened its impact to the community.  Before COVID pandemic, three successive years (2017, 2018, 2019) with "Record-High" number of twenty-four students (17 female) supported to attend extracurricular training and professional development/networking at Texas Hydro Geo Workshop.  In 2020 summer, "Record-High" number of thirty-five students signed up for HAZWOPER (Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response) 40-Hours training to enhance their employment opportunities in environmental sectors.  SHIP-GEO continued to provide junior faculty with many opportunities and experience for project operation, management, planning logistic, and additional student mentoring.  SHIP-GEO had provided senior faculty with mentoring/guiding one additional junior faculty member and two non-tenure track faculty. SHIP-GEO had provided platform for faculty to "re-connect" with alumni (invited talks) and strengthen collaborations.  SHIP-GEO had engaged a wider audience at UTRGV and RGV community as a whole for building Hispanic STEM workforce for geosciences and STEM.  SHIP-GEO team continues to reach out to local museums to develop geosciences/history relations exhibits. PI team members were also invited for Advising Day at the South Texas Community College and several local high schools.
